Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A virtual workshop on conducting language research online: Enhancing the resilience of the language sciences in a time of social distancing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This project supports a five-week long virtual workshop for language scientists. The purpose is to train language scientists to conduct language studies with human subjects over the Internet. There are two primary motivations. First, in response to the COVID-19 crisis, laboratories around the world have ceased in-person human data collection. That means ideas being left untested, discoveries not being made, students not getting trained, and human talent left untapped. Second, Internet-based experiments offer a number of advantages for research: they can be cheaper, faster, provide better data, and allow researchers to work on questions that are impossible to study in the lab. In fact, a number of researchers have pointed out that language science research would be advanced if more studies could be undertaken using Internet-based data collection. Thus, by enabling researchers to rapidly move research online, this project will not only help mitigate the costs of the COVID-19 crisis, but will result in a science that is more robust and faster-moving than before the crisis. The workshop will be free and open to all. All materials will be available online for individuals who could not attend the live workshop. <br/><br/>In each of the first four weeks, there will be a 2 to 3 hour live video presentation, including a live question and answer (Q&A) session. Each presentation will be followed several days later by a live, message board-based Q&A. During the fifth week, there will be an additional message board-based Q&A. Topics will include technical skills, such as using popular software platforms, as well as other research implementation skills, such as handling ethics issues and subject recruitment. The workshop will be facilitated by the teams experienced in the design and use of two robust software packages for online experiments.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We offered an online, multi-week workshop to train researchers in methods and technical skills for moving their in-person human subjects research to online. Online research is an increasingly popular method for human subjects research, and the closure of in-person research labs as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the shift towards online data collection. In collaboration with Joshua Hartshorne?s team at Boston College, we broadcast six workshop sessions on YouTube Live. These sessions covered a popular tool for conducting online research (jsPsych; https://www.jspsych.org), ways to adapt lab-based methodologies to the internet-based data collection, and a new tool for creating a virtual laboratory on the web (Pushkin; https://languagelearninglab.gitbook.io/pushkin/). The sessions involved live audience interaction through YouTube?s chat features, allowing presenters to answer questions and adapt content to audience needs.

Demand for training in online data collection was high at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. 1,371 people registered to participate in at least one of the live sessions. The recordings have remained on YouTube since the live broadcast in the summer of 2020 and have accumulated over 11,000 total views as of July 2021. We also saw a corresponding increase in traffic to the jsPsych website, peaking at about 3,000 sessions per week during the workshop. Since the workshop, approximately 800 questions have been posted on the jsPsych support forum. Funding from this project has allowed us to dedicate more resources to answering these questions and helping scientists move their research online.

The website that we developed for the workshop (https://www.movingresearchonline.info) contains all of the session recordings and links to relevant resources including documentation, examples, and ways to get support.

All of the materials developed for the workshop will remain freely available online.
